posts.name: Marcelino Chua
posts.cooked:
Hi All,

I converted a VH109 to a VH113 from here

When I power cycle the AP, the configuration for all the SSIDs disappear and I have to reconfigure it.

Is this a known problem?

I‚Äôm using the 1.2.9 version: VH-109_AP_PRACTICE_1.2.9-02102025.img.enc

Thanks, Marcelino

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: This is expected behavior, The VH-113 resets to a known state when power cycled.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Marcelino Chua
posts.cooked:
Hi FletcherS7,

Good to know! Thanks!

Is there a way to make it persistent across power cycles? We are looking to set up a VH113 as a practice field AP that we can turn on when needed.

Thanks, Marcelino

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: No, there is not. You need to have some sort of system to configure it every boot.

Marcelino:

practice field AP

Are you planning on running more than one robot on the field? If not, you can use the radio firmware variant but set it to access point mode. This would be persistent across power cycles. If you do need it for multiple robots, the you will have to put in the SSIDs each time.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
That is expected. As in real FMS environment every match had different setting. If you are not using FMS , flash the regular firmware and use AP mode.

Fun fact: linksys router flashed with FMS firmware had the exact behaver. As it carries the same backend API server .

You wouldn‚Äôt be able to use this firmware without a network switch with VLAN support anyway. The web server is under VLAN 100 and it‚Äôs untagged. That is the reason why you could access it without plugging it in. To take full advantage of this firmware you would need a managed network switch and the computer running FMS or Cheesy Arena. wireless side won‚Äôt have access to VLAN 100 by design.

Flash the firmware back to vh-109 if you don‚Äôt know what you are doing.

If you want more readings‚Ä¶

An alternative field management system for the FIRST Robotics Competition. - Team254/cheesy-arena

and

The purpose of this document is to provide an insight to the functional structure and method by which the FIELD MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (FMS) is implemented on a typical FRC field. All rules information ...

And if you really want to use this firmware, you might want to get yourself a Cisco Catalyst 3500-series Layer 3 managed switch and use it with Cheesy Arena. The recommended model is WS-3560G-48TS-E which is widely available in eBay and Facebook marketplace.

posts.name: Marcelino Chua
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the reply!

I‚Äôve gotten it to work‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm just asking if there‚Äôs a way to make it persistent across reboots‚Ä¶ and it seems the answer is no‚Ä¶ unless we can use a raspberry pi (or something) to dynamically reconfigure it on power up (I don‚Äôt suppose there is a REST API available for the VH113?)

Anyway, FYI, I‚Äôve got a Juniper SRX that I‚Äôve configured with the required VLANs to accept the trunk coming out of the AP. This SRX can also serve as a managed switch so that we could hard wire to the driver stations for the different vlans‚Ä¶ But to make it even better, I‚Äôve also got a separate Eero AP that we use for our team to get on the wifi network - which then connects through this SRX to the ‚ÄúVH113‚Äù AP. Which is then 6ghz connected to the VH109 on the robots.

So from the wifi connection to the Eero, we could reach the robots - AND reach the Internet at the same time through our internet gateway - connected to the SRX. This is great for coding teams‚Ä¶

The only problem is if we power the VH109/113 down, we‚Äôll need to reconfigure it‚Ä¶ but‚Ä¶ given that we‚Äôll be using a VH117 with the real VH113 that we‚Äôre waiting for, theoretically, the reconfiguration problem should only happen if we get a power outage.

So IS there an API by chance? Would intercepting the configuration call with Postman give me the answer I need?

BTW, we may eventually use FMS (with cheesyarena) but that‚Äôs a longer term goal‚Ä¶

Thanks for your help! Marcelino

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
There is an API. Here‚Äôs the source code

posts.name: Marcelino Chua
posts.cooked: Hi httpmaster, yes we are planning on running more than one robot on the field. We did use the normal AP variant to start with but the 2.4Ghz was really noisy for us and kept dropping connection with the driver station‚Ä¶ We also had the goal of being able to connect to a field net (wifi) that could be used by our team members with older laptops that didn‚Äôt have Wifi 6e. We also did do the dual VH109 radio, but the limitation there is we need 2 radios per robot‚Ä¶

posts.name: Marcelino Chua
posts.cooked: Cool! I‚Äôll take a look at this‚Ä¶ Thanks FletcherS7!

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
There is an API. You could create a script that call this API. For the old linksys as I have ssh access to the router. I could do some black magic on startup to do these kind of thing on the device. However, I think new radio firmware blocked ssh access thus you might need to create something on your own computer.

$ curl http://10.0.100.2:8081/configuration -XPOST -d ‚Äò{ ‚Äúchannel‚Äù: 93, ‚ÄúchannelBandwidth‚Äù: ‚ÄúHT20‚Äù, ‚ÄúredVlans‚Äù: ‚Äú40_50_60‚Äù, ‚ÄúblueVlans‚Äù: ‚Äú70_80_90‚Äù, ‚ÄústationConfigurations‚Äù: { ‚Äúred1‚Äù: {‚Äússid‚Äù: ‚Äú1111‚Äù, ‚ÄúwpaKey‚Äù: ‚Äú11111111‚Äù}, ‚Äúblue2‚Äù: {‚Äússid‚Äù: ‚Äú5555‚Äù, ‚ÄúwpaKey‚Äù: ‚Äú55555555‚Äù} }, ‚ÄúsyslogIpAddress‚Äù: ‚Äú10.0.100.40‚Äù }‚Äô New configuration received and will be applied asynchronously.

I consulted ChatGPT and it comes up with this script.

You should get the idea‚Ä¶
